topic: Finding and navigating all links on a webpage using a screen reader
ground truth: JAWS can list all links on a webpage in a dialog for quick navigation.
most similar: JAWS can list all links on a webpage in a dialog for quick navigation.

topic: Customizing a screen reader with add-ons, extensions, or scripts
ground truth: NVDA is open source and allows community-developed add-ons.
most similar: Screen readers can interact with dialog boxes and pop-ups.

topic: How screen readers interpret document structure (headings, tables, forms, landmarks)
ground truth: Screen readers can expose document structure like tables, lists, and headings.
most similar: Screen readers can expose document structure like tables, lists, and headings.

topic: Using braille output alongside speech in screen readers
ground truth: Screen readers can present information through both speech and braille simultaneously.
most similar: Screen readers can present information through both speech and braille simultaneously.

topic: Different ways screen magnifiers enlarge content (full screen, lens, docked, etc.)
ground truth: Windows Magnifier offers full-screen, lens, and docked viewing modes.
most similar: Windows Magnifier offers full-screen, lens, and docked viewing modes.

topic: Techniques for improving mouse or cursor visibility when zoomed in
ground truth: Pointer trails improve visibility of fast cursor movement.
most similar: Cursor enlargement makes the mouse pointer easier to locate on screen.

topic: Visual adjustments that reduce glare and improve contrast for readability
ground truth: Mobile accessibility includes color inversion and contrast settings.
most similar: High-contrast themes improve readability of system interfaces.

topic: How refreshable braille displays present digital text
ground truth: Refreshable braille displays use moving pins to form braille characters.
most similar: Refreshable braille displays use moving pins to form braille characters.

topic: Methods for typing directly in braille on electronic devices
ground truth: Braille Screen Input lets users type braille directly on a touchscreen.
most similar: Braille keyboards allow direct braille input to computers.

topic: Using braille for proofreading and identifying spelling or formatting issues
ground truth: Braille output supports proofreading by revealing spelling errors.
most similar: Braille output supports proofreading by revealing spelling errors.

topic: How smartphone screen readers enable navigation through touch gestures
ground truth: VoiceOver on iOS uses gestures to navigate and activate interface elements.
most similar: Mobile screen readers announce focused controls and their roles.

topic: Using mobile devices with speech while keeping the screen visually private or off
ground truth: VoiceOverâ€™s screen curtain turns off the display while keeping audio active.
most similar: VoiceOver can present content in braille through paired devices.

topic: Connecting and using braille with smartphones, including braille input methods
ground truth: Braille displays connect to computers via USB or Bluetooth.
most similar: Braille displays can pair with smartphones for mobile access.

topic: Operating a computer primarily through the keyboard instead of a mouse
ground truth: Keyboard navigation allows access to menus without a mouse.
most similar: Keyboard navigation allows access to menus without a mouse.

topic: Identifying which window, control, or interface element is currently active
ground truth: Focus indicators highlight the active control on screen.
most similar: Focus indicators highlight the active control on screen.

topic: Customizing visual and motion settings on a desktop for accessibility
ground truth: High-contrast themes replace interface colors to improve text visibility.
most similar: Desktop accessibility can be customized for individual applications.

topic: Using GPS-based tools for pedestrian navigation with audio guidance
ground truth: GPS navigation apps provide turn-by-turn audio directions for pedestrians.
most similar: GPS navigation apps provide turn-by-turn audio directions for pedestrians.

topic: Technologies that support indoor navigation in large buildings

most similar: Indoor navigation can use Wi-Fi positioning.

topic: Tools for detecting and avoiding obstacles while traveling
ground truth: Wearable sensors can detect obstacles at head height.
most similar: Some devices detect head-level obstacles for safety.

topic: Non-visual ways of understanding direction, distance, and orientation
ground truth: Orientation tools can announce compass directions.
most similar: Wearable devices can provide spatial audio cues for orientation.

topic: Using a camera or phone to read printed documents aloud
ground truth: Mobile OCR apps can read printed mail aloud using a phone camera.
most similar: Mobile OCR apps can read printed mail aloud using a phone camera.

topic: Factors that affect the accuracy of text recognition from images
ground truth: OCR accuracy improves with good lighting and flat documents.
most similar: OCR can identify text in low-contrast images.

topic: Recognizing text in real-world environments (signs, labels, handwriting)
ground truth: OCR can identify text in photographs of signs.
most similar: OCR can identify text in photographs of signs.

topic: Sending recognized text to screen readers or braille displays

most similar: OCR can export text to braille displays.

topic: Hands-free ways to manage reminders, messages, and phone calls
ground truth: Users can ask assistants to read incoming messages aloud.
most similar: Voice assistants can set reminders using spoken commands.

topic: Using voice assistants to control devices in a home environment
ground truth: Smart speakers support hands-free control of home devices.
most similar: Some systems provide voice feedback for smart appliances.

topic: Voice-based control of accessibility features and settings
ground truth: Assistants can control accessibility settings like screen readers.
most similar: Assistants can control accessibility features through voice.

topic: Standalone devices for reading printed text without relying on a smartphone

most similar: Mobile OCR apps can read printed mail aloud using a phone camera.

topic: Tactile and audio-based hardware that conveys information without visuals

most similar: Some braille devices include audio output as well as tactile output.

topic: Learning to use screen readers efficiently with keyboard commands
